title: How to charge an iPhone with Magnets!
description: Ever wonder how long a magnet can last? You can grab your Anker PowerCore Magnetic 5K HERE:  The Magnets should be good for the next 5,000 years or so. (If you have any issues after year 4,000 come find me.) The Anker Nano II 45W is here:   Anker PowerCore 10K Wireless:   Today we are going to take apart Ankers new wireless powerbank. No more cables to worry about in your backpack or purse. Just slip this Anker 5K charger into place, and its juicing up your phone without plugging anything in. The future is here.    MyTeardown Skin is HERE:   Anker is named as the Official Charging Partner of JerryRigEverything:    Get my razor knife here!   *Follow me for updates!* Instagram:  Facebook:  Twitter:   LARGE tool kit:  Travel Tool Kit:  Mega Tool Kit:  Plastic Pry tools:  Metal phone opening tool:  Replacement phone parts:   The camera I used to film this video:  The Lens I used for this video:  Wide angle lens:  And this Metabones adapter:  This is the drone I use:   TO SEND ME STUFF: See my P.O. Box on my 'About page':   JerryRigEverything assumes no liability for property damage or injury incurred as a result of any of the information contained in this video.  JerryRigEverything recommends safe practices when working with power tools, automotive lifts, lifting tools, jack stands, electrical equipment, blunt instruments, chemicals, lubricants, expensive electronics, or any other tools or equipment seen or implied in this video.  Due to factors beyond the control of JerryRigEverything, no information contained in this video shall create any express or implied warranty or guarantee of any particular result.  Any injury, damage or loss that may result from improper use of these tools, equipment, or the information contained in this video is the sole responsibility of the user and not JerryRigEverything. Only attempt your own repairs if you can accept personal responsibility for the results, whether they are good or bad.
transcript: Today we have something interesting. Apple's been using wireless charging now for about 4 years, but only recently did they start adding some pretty sweet looking magnets to the back of their iPhones to facilitate the process. You can tell by the circle of magnets that surround the outer edge of the copper induction coil. I'm a little biased, of course, but I think it makes my Teardown Skin for the iPhone look super cool. Well my channel's sponsor, Anker, decided to run with this new magnetic magsafe technology and threw some equally strong magnets inside of one of their power banks. So now there's no cords involved when you need some backup juice. It lines up by itself and magnetically stays attached to the phone with some pretty good force. Shaking it around from the phone side or even holding it by the charger, everything still stays connected. Today we're going to find out how this sorcery works from the inside and see if the PowerCore's magnets are oriented in the same direction as Apple's. Let's get started. [Intro] The PowerCore 5K is pretty small. We'll get to the internal battery in just a second but the outside is covered with a grippy rubberized surface and feels pretty solid. It's got a power button that will turn on the wireless charging ability, and a few LED indicator lights that show how much charge is left inside of the bank, along with an additional USB-C port to charge other devices that might not be magsafe compatible. It looks like it only charges one device at a time. The wireless charging of the iPhone turns off when I plug in my Note 10 Plus, but it is nice to have options. There's another larger wireless power bank from Anker called the PowerCore 10K. It doesn't have the internal magnets, but it is still wireless and can charge three things at the same time. But today we're after those magnets. You might be asking yourself, 'Hey Jerry, how long do magnets even last?' And I'm glad you asked. Magnets, like the ones found inside of the iPhone and the Anker PowerCore, actually don't last forever. They lose about 1% of their holding power every hundred years or so. So in like 5,000 years, we'll drop to about 50% of the original holding capacity. Hit that subscribe button so you don't miss the video where we test that one out. You also might have noticed by now that this power bank is not designed to come apart. There is a seam around the outer edge and we're definitely making progress. But with everything glued shut, we need some brute force. So far we see some cushy foam tape inside of that plastic housing, kind of like the foam we saw inside of GM's electric hummer. And also, like that Hummer, Anker's power bank is using a pouch style lithium battery, like we see in most cell phones. 5,000 milliamp hours to be exact. And while this battery is indeed much larger than the iPhone 12's internal battery, due to the energy lost while using inductive charging, it'll be giving the iPhone about one full charge or 17 additional hours of video. The underside of the power bank is where things start to get more interesting. This is where we find the copper induction coil, as well as the neodymium magnets embedded into the back plastics. Let's start with the magnets. Personally, I didn't notice that the magsafe charger isn't just a circle of magnets. It's actually shaped like a flower, with a stem and then a circle of petals up top. The magnet at the base making up the stem of the flower is what keeps things aligned. And the circle part keeps things centered around that copper coil. Thumbs up for that. Learn something new every day. And it does a pretty good job. The tiny magnets from the power bank can support the full weight of the phone. Magnets are pretty crazy. Let's see if the coil will still function without the magnets...and it looks like it does. It doesn't lock on or center itself anymore, but can still act as a normal wireless charging pad, even with the exterior now removed. The coil itself is a bit thicker than the coils we normally find in smartphones, probably because it's giving power instead of just receiving it. It can charge up the phone at 5 watts, and looks like it's coated with some kind of soft, white material. Overall it's pretty cool. Interesting to see a full on powerbank adapting to the magsafe technology, even if it is only using 5 watts. If you want to charge faster, of course, Anker does have their Nano 2, which packs 45 watts of juice into a small little package. Charging with a cable is quite a bit more efficient than wireless charging, even if it is a little less futuristic. Either way, I think it was cool to explore the insides. Let me know if you want me to take apart one of those Nano 2's. I don't think we've ever done a charging brick before. Might be fun. Come hang out with me on Instagram and Twitter. And thanks a ton for watching. I'll see you around.
